name: The Truth About the KJV of the Bible Online Quiz | Religion | 10 Questions

questions.text: What is the first verse in the Bible in the KJV?
questions.correct: "In the beginning God created the Heaven and the earth."
options: "For God so loved the world He gave his only begotten Son that whosoever believeth in Him shall not perish but have everlasting life."
"In the beginning God created the Heaven and the earth."
"God saw it, and it was good."
questions.explanation:
"In the beginning God created the Heaven and the earth."

	The first verse can be found in Genesis 1:1. Genesis tells the creation story of how the world was first created.

questions.text: Who was the only female judge in the King James Version of the Bible?
questions.explanation:
Deborah.

	The name Deborah means bee. There were two Deborahs mentioned in the Bible - the judge and Rebekah's nurse. You can read about the judge Deborah in the book of Judges, chapters 4 and 5.

questions.text: How many books make up the major prophets in the King James Version of the Old Testament in the Bible?
questions.explanation:
5.

	The major prophet books are: Isaiah, Jeremiah, Lamentations, Ezekiel and Daniel. They are not called major because they are more important than the minor prophets. They are called major because their books are much longer than those of the minor prophets.

questions.text: Who is credited with writing most of the Psalms in the book of Psalms?
questions.explanation:
David.

	David was a shepherd when he was younger. When he got older he became a king. Christians believe that Jesus' lineage was through King David.

questions.text: What does the twenty-third Psalm start with?
options: "O lord, rebuke me not in thy wrath: neither chasten me in thy hot displeasure."
"Preserve me, O God: for in thee do I put my trust."
"Truly my soul waiteth upon God: from him cometh my salvation."
questions.explanation:
"The Lord is my shepherd."

	The others are from Psalms 16, 38, and 62.The full Psalm 23 says: "The LORD is my shepherd; I shall not want.He maketh me to lie down in green pastures: he leadeth me beside the still waters.He restoreth my soul: he leadeth me in the paths of righteousness for his name's sake.Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil: for thou art with me; thy rod and thy staff they comfort me.Thou preparest a table before me in the presence of mine enemies: thou anointest my head with oil; my cup runneth over.Surely goodness and mercy shall follow me all the days of my life: and I will dwell in the house of the LORD for ever."

questions.text: What verse is the first verse in the KJV that mentions some form of the word love?
questions.explanation:
Genesis 22:2.

	It says in Genesis 22:2, "And he said, Take now thy son, thine only son Isaac, whom thou lovest, and get thee into the land of Moriah; and offer him there for a burnt offering upon one of the mountains which I will tell thee of." Isaac was Abraham and Sarah's son.

questions.text: What is the first verse in the KJV that mentions the word health?
questions.explanation:
Genesis 43:28.

	It says in Genesis 43:28, "And they answered, Thy servant our father is in good health, he is yet alive. And they bowed down their heads, and made obeisance."Obeisance is another word for respect.

questions.text: What is the last word in the KJV of the Bible?
questions.explanation:
amen.

	"Amen" means so be it. It is the last word in many books of the Bible as well as the last word often spoken when praying. The last word can be found in Revelation 22:21.

questions.text: What are the first two words of the KJV New Testament?
questions.explanation:
"The book".

	Matthew 1:1 says, "The book of the generation of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham." The first chapter of Matthew gives the genealogy of Jesus Christ.

questions.text: What is the first verse in the KJV in which the word "dog" is used?
questions.explanation:
Exodus 11:7.

	It says in Exodus 11:7, "But against any of the children of Israel shall not a dog move his tongue, against man or beast: that ye may know how that the LORD doth put a difference between the Egyptians and Israel." In another story in the Bible found in I Kings, a woman named Jezebel is eaten by dogs.
